1-2-209   County staff
§ 1-2-200. CREATION, POWERS.
   (A)   There shall be a Frederick County Veterans Advisory Council (VAC).
   (B)   Among its powers and duties, the VAC shall:
      (1)   Collaborate with established military Veteran oriented service
organizations to evaluate, develop and promote new and existing programs and
services for Veterans and their families within Frederick County.
      (2)   Collaborate with other County Commissions, Boards and Councils, and
County staff with regard to policies, programs, and concerns related to
Veterans' interest.
      (3)   Collaborate with the County Executive and County Council to develop
and promote programs and services in the State and County related to the needs
of Veterans and their families.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018)
§ 1-2-201. COMPOSITION.
   (A)   Subject to confirmation by the County Council, the County Executive
shall appoint up to 7 members to the VAC, all of whom shall be registered
voters and residents of Frederick County, not less than 4 of whom are honorably
discharged veterans.
   (B)   Three members may be non-veterans, who represent a variety of
organizations that provide services to veterans such as:
      (1)   A post-secondary educational institution; or
      (2)   A member of a Veterans' Service Organization.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018; Bill No. 25-04, 4-1-2025)
§ 1-2-202. EX-OFFICIO NON-VOTING ADVISORY MEMBERS.
   (A)   A representative from the U. S. Department of Veterans Affairs, such
as:
      (1)   Veterans Administration Vet Center;
      (2)   Veterans Administration - Veteran Experience Office; or
      (3)   Veterans Administration - Community Based Outpatient Clinic / Fort
Detrick location.
   (B)   The Director of the Frederick County Workforce Services, or the
Director's designee.
   (C)   The Director of the Frederick County Health Department, Behavioral
Health Services Division, or the Director's designee.
   (D)   A Veteran Liaison from Frederick Memorial Hospital or one of its
affiliates.
   (E)   A member of the Frederick County Council.
   (F)   A member of the Maryland General Assembly who represents Frederick
County.
   (G)   A representative from the office of a member of the U.S. Congress who
represents Frederick County.
   (H)   A representative from the Maryland Department of Veterans and Military
Families that represents Frederick County.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018; Bill No. 25-04, 4-1-2025)
§ 1-2-203. TERMS, REAPPOINTMENTS, VACANCIES.
   (A)   The term of office of each of the members shall be for a period of 4
years, effective for all new members appointed following the effective date of
this bill.
   (B)   Members may be reappointed, but may not serve more than 4 full
consecutive 2-year terms or 2 full consecutive 4-year terms.
   (C)   Vacancies shall be filled on the same basis as the original
appointments for the unexpired terms. Members shall continue in office until
their successors are appointed and qualified.
   (D)   A VAC member may be removed by the County Executive for cause.
   (E)   If an individual is a veteran that serves on the Veterans Advisory
Council as an ex-officio, they must be honorably discharged from the United
States military.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018; Bill No. 25-04, 4-1-2025)
§ 1-2-204. CHAIR, VICE-CHAIR.
   The Chair and Vice-Chair will be selected by the members of the VAC.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018)
§ 1-2-205. MEETINGS AND QUORUM.
   (A)   The VAC shall meet as frequently as determined by the VAC, but not
less than quarterly. Meeting locations shall be determined by the VAC Chair and
shall be in Frederick County, open to the public and ADA accessible.
   (B)   Notice of the date, time, and place of the VAC meetings shall meet the
requirements of the Maryland Open Meetings Act.
   (C)   A majority of the VAC voting members shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of regular business.
   (D)   Any voting member of the VAC who fails to attend at least 50% of the
meetings during any period of 12 consecutive months shall be considered to have
resigned. Subject to confirmation by the County Council, the County Executive
shall appoint a replacement.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018)
§ 1-2-206. RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The VAC shall adopt rules to govern its procedures and activities.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018)
§ 1-2-207. COMPENSATION.
   Members of the VAC shall receive no compensation for their services.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018)
§ 1-2-208. [REPORTS.]
   On or before July 1 of each year, the VAC shall provide a report to the
County Executive and the County Council on its activities and progress in
meeting its goals. The VAC shall post the report on the VAC website.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018)
§ 1-2-209. COUNTY STAFF.
   A county staff member should be designated by the County Executive as a
liaison to assist the VAC.
(Bill No. 18-11, 5-1-2018)
ARTICLE XIII: SUSTAINABLE MONOCACY COMMISSION (§§ 1-2-300 — 1-2-307)
Section
   
1-2-300   Creation, purpose
   
1-2-301   Membership
   
1-2-302   Terms, reappointments, vacancies
   
1-2-303   Chair, Vice-Chair
   
1-2-304   Meetings and quorum
   
1-2-305   Rules and regulations
   
1-2-306   Compensation
   
1-2-307   County staff
§ 1-2-300. CREATION, PURPOSE.
   (A)   There shall be a Frederick County Sustainable Monocacy Commission
(SMC).
   (B)   Among its duties, the SMC shall:
      (1)   Recommend policies that improve water quality, maintain and restore
the ecological health and productivity of the Monocacy River and its
tributaries, and conserve and protect wildlife habitat, the natural, cultural,
and scenic character of the Monocacy River and its tributaries flowing in and
through Frederick County.
      (2)   Review studies, policies, and rules formulated by federal, state,
and local government agencies that concern or affect the Monocacy River and its
tributaries, and to comment and provide advice on such proposals as
appropriate.
      (3)   Review and make recommendations on federal, state, county, and
local programs, policies, regulations, and public and private projects, which
the SMC believes may have an impact on the Monocacy River and its tributaries.
      (4)   Review and make recommendations concerning the implementation of
the most recent Frederick County approved Monocacy Scenic River
Management Plan and to help fulfill the other objectives as outlined in the
document.
      (5)   Educate the public and increase awareness about the importance of
the Monocacy River's environmental, cultural, and recreational resources, and
provide information related to actions that can be taken by individuals and
communities to reduce pollution, conserve water, and promote a healthy and
productive Monocacy River and its tributaries.
      (6)   Prepare a written report outlining the activities, goals, and
accomplishments of the SMC annually or as appropriate. This report shall be
submitted to the County Executive and County Council, and posted on the SMC
website.
      (7)   Meet and collaborate with the Carroll County River Board (or its
equivalent board) annually or as needed and agreed upon by the two boards.
(Bill No. 19-17, 1-21-2020)
§ 1-2-301. MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   Number. Subject to confirmation by the County Council, the County
Executive shall appoint up to 13 members to the SMC, all of whom shall be
residents of Frederick County. The elected official from the City of Frederick,
or designee, shall be a non-voting member of the SMC. The elected official from
the County Council, or designee, shall be a non-voting member of the SMC.
   (B)   Composition.
      (1)   The SMC shall consist of:
         (a)   Two owners of property contiguous to Monocacy River;
         (b)   One owner of property contiguous to a named or unnamed tributary
of the Monocacy River;
         (c)   Two individuals who do not reside on property which is
contiguous to Monocacy River;
         (d)   One elected official of The City of Frederick, or designee, non-
voting;
         (e)   One elected official of the County Council, or designee, non-
voting;
         (f)   One representative of the agricultural community;
         (g)   One student representative enrolled in a high school or
postsecondary institution;
         (h)   Three individuals having educational expertise or experience in
the fields of biology, ecology, chemistry, earth sciences, environmental
education, natural resources, or related fields; and
         (i)   One member from the general public.
(Bill No. 19-17, 1-21-2020; Bill No. 24-02, 4-2- 2024)
§ 1-2-302. TERMS, REAPPOINTMENTS, VACANCIES.
   (A)   The term of office of each of the members shall be for a period of
four years, based on the county's fiscal year, July 1 to June 30. The terms of
the members shall be staggered so that no more than five members are replaced
each year.
   (B)   Members may be reappointed, but may not serve more than two full
consecutive four-year terms.
   (C)   Vacancies shall be filled on the same basis as the original
appointments for the unexpired terms. Members shall continue in office until
their successors are appointed and qualified.
(Bill No. 19-17, 1-21-2020; Bill No. 24-02, 4-2- 2024)
§ 1-2-303. CHAIR, VICE-CHAIR.
   The Chair and Vice-Chair will be selected by the members of the SMC.
(Bill No. 19-17, 1-21-2020)
§ 1-2-304. MEETINGS AND QUORUM.
   (A)   The SMC shall meet as frequently as determined by the SMC, but not
less than twice per calendar year. Meeting locations shall be determined by the
SMC Chair and shall be in Frederick County, open to the public, and ADA
accessible.
   (B)   Notice of the date, time, and place of the SMC meetings shall meet the
requirements of the Maryland Open Meetings Act.
   (C)   A majority of the SMC voting members shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of regular business.
   (D)   Any voting member of the SMC who fails to attend at least 50% of the
meetings during any period of 24 consecutive months shall be considered to have
resigned. Subject to confirmation by the County Council, the County Executive
shall appoint a replacement.
(Bill No. 19-17, 1-21-2020)
§ 1-2-305. RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The SMC shall adopt rules to govern its procedures and activities.
(Bill No. 19-17, 1-21-2020)
§ 1-2-306. COMPENSATION.
   Members of the SMC shall receive no compensation for their services.
(Bill No. 19-17, 1-21-2020)
§ 1-2-307. COUNTY STAFF.
   A county staff member will be designated by the County Executive as a
liaison to assist the SMC in its duties.
(Bill No. 19-17, 1-21-2020)
ARTICLE XIV: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE COORDINATING COUNCIL (§§ 1-2-400 — 1-2-406)
Section
   
1-2-400   Creation, duties
   
1-2-401   Composition
   
1-2-402   Chair, Vice-Chair
   
1-2-403   Rules
   
1-2-404   Advocacy
   
1-2-405   Compensation
   
1-2-406   Reporting
§ 1-2-400. CREATION, DUTIES.
   (A)   There shall be a Frederick County Domestic Violence Coordinating
Council (Coordinating Council).
   (B)   The Coordinating Council will meet at least four times each year.
   (C)   The Coordinating Council shall:
      (1)   Advise the County Executive, County Council, and Criminal Justice
Coordinating Commission and its members on policies, programs, and legislation
necessary to prevent domestic violence and assist victims and their families
with safety, stability and services;
      (2)   Promote and facilitate an effective community wide victim-centered
response to domestic violence, including a well-coordinated, multi-disciplinary
approach to all programs serving victims of domestic violence and their
families;
      (3)   Coordinate with the Maryland Network Against Domestic Violence and
all other county, state, federal, and non-governmental agencies, committees,
boards, commissions, and organizations that operate, monitor, provide education
or technical assistance or coordinate domestic violence programs or services in
the county to maximize the effectiveness of these programs and services;
      (4)   Develop recommendations to improve the coordination and
effectiveness of county, state, federal, and non-governmental multi-
disciplinary, victim-centered efforts regarding domestic violence, including
prevention, intervention, treatment, law enforcement, prosecution, correctional
and advocacy efforts;
      (5)   Cooperate with any relevant departments, agencies, committees,
boards, commissions, and organizations to periodically review the quality and
sufficiency of programs and facilities available to domestic violence victims,
offenders and their children throughout the county;
      (6)   Obtain, evaluate and assist in implementing the recommendations of
the county's Domestic Violence Fatality Review Team established under Md. Code
Ann., Title 4, Subtitle 7, the Family Law Article;
      (7)   Obtain and evaluate statistical data, reports, and other
information related to domestic violence, including information regarding
innovative efforts by other governmental and non-governmental entities, as
necessary to implement the requirements of this section; and
      (8)   Subject to § 1-2-404, advocate for policies or legislation at the
county, state and federal levels that would improve efforts to address domestic
violence issues, including prevention, intervention, treatment, law
enforcement, prosecution, correctional and advocacy efforts.
(Bill No. 20-09, 7-21-2020)
§ 1-2-401. COMPOSITION.
   (A)   The Coordinating Council shall include the following:
      (1)   A member of the County Council;
      (2)   The Administrative Judge for Frederick County District Court or
designee of the Administrative Judge;
      (3)   The Administrative Judge for the Frederick County Circuit Court or
designee of the Administrative Judge;
      (4)   The State's Attorney for Frederick County or designee of the
State's Attorney;
      (5)   The Regional Director of the Division of Parole and Probation,
Maryland Department of Public Safety and Corrections or designee of the
Regional Director;
      (6)   The Frederick County Sheriff or designee of the Frederick County
Sheriff;
      (7)   The Chief of the City of Frederick Police Department or designee of
the Chief;
      (8)   The Forensic Nursing Services Coordinator at Frederick Health
Hospital or designee of the Coordinator;
      (9)   The President of a comprehensive domestic violence program serving
county residents, or designee of the President;
      (10)   The Director of the Frederick County office of the Maryland
Department of Human Services or designee of the Director;
      (11)   The Director of Behavioral Health Services, Frederick County
Health Department or designee of the Director;
      (12)   The Superintendent of Frederick County Public Schools or designee
of the Superintendent; and
      (13)   The Director of the Frederick County Child Advocacy Center or
designee of the Director.
   (B)   Subject to confirmation by the County Council, with input from the
Coordinating Council members listed in §
1-2-401(A), the County Executive must appoint the following individuals to
serve three-year terms on the Coordinating Council:
      (1)   One attorney with experience representing victims of domestic
violence to serve a three-year term;
      (2)   One attorney with experience representing criminal defendants of
domestic violence charges to serve a three-year term;
      (3)   One member of the public with a demonstrated interest in domestic
violence issues, with preference for a survivor of domestic violence, to serve
a three-year term; and
      (4)   One student member with a demonstrated interest in addressing
domestic and dating violence to serve a one-year term on the Coordinating
Council. The student member's term may be renewed for one additional year. The
student member must be a high school or college student who resides in the
county when initially appointed.
   (C)   All members of the Coordinating Council are voting members.
   (D)   If the State's Attorney agrees, their office will provide the primary
staff for the Coordinating Council:
      (1)   At the request of the State's Attorney, the state courts and
agencies listed in this section and the county agencies listed in this section
may provide additional staff assistance to the Coordinating Council.
(Bill No. 20-09, 7-21-2020)
§ 1-2-402. CHAIR, VICE-CHAIR.
   The Coordinating Council must elect a Chair and Vice-Chair from among its
members to serve two-year terms.
(Bill No. 20-09, 7-21-2020)
§ 1-2-403. RULES.
   The Coordinating Council shall adopt rules to govern its procedures and
activities.
(Bill No. 20-09, 7-21-2020)
§ 1-2-404. ADVOCACY.
   The Coordinating Council as an entity may not engage in any advocacy efforts
at the local, state or federal levels unless these efforts are approved by a
majority of the members. This section does not bar individual members or
represented agencies and organizations from engaging in advocacy independent of
the Coordinating Council.
(Bill No. 20-09, 7-21-2020)
§ 1-2-405. COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Coordinating Council shall receive no compensation for their
services.
(Bill No. 20-09, 7-21-2020)
§ 1-2-406. REPORTING.
   The Coordinating Council may make reports and recommendations to the County
Executive and County Council from time to time as the Coordinating Council
finds appropriate but must report annually.
(Bill No. 20-09, 7-21-2020)
ARTICLE XV: IMMIGRATION AFFAIRS COMMISSION (§§ 1-2-500 — 1-2-507)
Section
   
1-2-500   Creation, duties
   
1-2-501   Composition
   
1-2-502   Terms, reappointments, vacancies
   
1-2-503   Chair, Vice-Chair
   
1-2-504   Meetings and quorum
   
1-2-505   Rules and regulations
   
1-2-506   Compensation
   
1-2-507   County staff
§ 1-2-500. CREATION, DUTIES.
   (A)   There shall be a Frederick County Immigrant Affairs Commission
(hereinafter referred to as "the Commission").
   (B)   The Commission shall act as an advisory body that serves as a means
for immigrant voices to be heard and understood, facilitates civic engagement
among immigrants, and recognizes and legitimizes issues of importance to
immigrants arriving and living in Frederick County.
   (C)   Among its responsibilities and duties, the Commission shall:
      (1)   Advise the County Executive and County Council on ways to enhance
and improve immigrant access to county services and resources; strengthen
opportunities for immigrants to participate in civic life; encourage dialogue
and understanding among immigrant communities and the non-immigrant community;
advocate on behalf of immigrants; and provide outreach from and community
feedback to the County Executive and County Council.
      (2)   Monitor, analyze, and make recommendations for existing or proposed
policies and actions, at all levels of government, for their impact on
immigrants.
      (3)   Assess, research, and compile data related to immigrant affairs in
Frederick County, including:
         (a)   Addressing immigrant needs and concerns;
         (b)   Bringing immigrant communities together for the purpose of
collective engagement;
         (c)   Access to and delivery of services and information tailored to
immigrants;
         (d)   Immigrant awareness of civil rights protections and related laws
and;
         (e)   Economic and workforce development opportunities for immigrants.
   (D)   The Commission's scope shall be limited to make recommendations only
on issues and groups under the exclusive authority of the county government.
The Commission's activities shall not include issues outside of the authority
of the county government, including those related to: the Frederick County
Board of Education, the Frederick County Sheriff, the Motor Vehicle
Administration, the State's Attorney's Office, the Frederick County Circuit
Court, the Frederick County District Court, Federal Immigration Policy or
Immigrations and Custom Enforcement (ICE).
      (1)   On or before July 1 of each year, the Commission shall submit an
annual report to the County Executive and County Council. The report should
include assessment findings and recommendations as identified above.
      (2)   Two years following the first meeting, the Commission will submit a
status report to the County Executive and County Council. The report should
include assessment findings and recommendations as identified above. Upon
submission of this report, the County Executive and County Council may submit
questions or requests to the Commission for additional information. The
Commission will have eight weeks to respond to any requests. Upon completion of
this review, the Council must vote whether to reauthorize the Commission.
(Bill No. 20-18, 2-2-2021)
§ 1-2-501. COMPOSITION.
   (A)   Subject to the confirmation of the County Council, the County
Executive must appoint the following individuals to serve on the Commission for
a three-year term unless otherwise noted:
      (1)   Two immigrants residing in the county who are not representatives
of an organization;
      (2)   Two representatives of the business community who are immigrants;
      (3)   Two representatives of community based organizations serving
immigrant populations in the county;
      (4)   Two representatives of a faith-based organization who are
immigrants;
      (5)   One attorney with experience in immigration law;
      (6)   One representative from a law enforcement agency in the county;
      (7)   One representative from the County Citizen Services Division;
      (8)   One representative of Frederick County Public Schools;
      (9)   One representative of Frederick Community College;
      (10)   One representative from the Frederick County Health Department;
      (11)   One student member with a demonstrated interest in immigrant
affairs to serve a one-year term on the Commission. The student's term may be
extended for one year. The student member must be a high school or college
student who resides in the county when initially appointed.
   (B)   The following individuals shall serve as ex-officio, non-voting
members with no terms assigned:
      (1)   A member of the County Council; and
      (2)   A member of the City of Frederick Board of Alderman.
(Bill No. 20-18, 2-2-2021)
§ 1-2-502. TERMS, REAPPOINTMENTS, VACANCIES.
   (A)   Members may be reappointed, but may not serve more than two full
consecutive three-year terms.
   (B)   Vacancies shall be filled on the same basis as the original
appointments for the unexpired terms. Members shall continue in office until
their successors are appointed and qualified.
(Bill No. 20-18, 2-2-2021)
§ 1-2-503. CHAIR, VICE-CHAIR.
   The Commission must elect a Chair and Vice-Chair from among its members to
serve one-year terms.
(Bill No. 20-18, 2-2-2021)
§ 1-2-504. MEETING AND QUORUM.
   (A)   The Commission shall meet with the frequency it determines necessary
to perform its functions but there shall be no less than six meetings annually.
   (B)   A majority of the Commission members shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of regular business.
   (C)   Any voting members of the Commission who fail to attend at least 50%
of the meetings during any period of 12 consecutive months shall be considered
to have resigned. Subject to confirmation by the County Council, the County
Executive shall appoint a replacement.
(Bill No. 20-18, 2-2-2021)
§ 1-2-505. RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Commission shall adopt rules to govern its procedures and activities.
(Bill No. 20-18, 2-2-2021)
§ 1-2-506. COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Commission shall receive no compensation for their services.
(Bill No. 20-18, 2-2-2021)
§ 1-2-507. COUNTY STAFF.
   A county staff member may be designated by the County Executive to assist
and support the Commission.
(Bill No. 20-18, 2-2-2021)
ARTICLE XVI: SMALL BUSINESS ADVISORY COMMISSION (§§ 1-2-600 — 1-2-605)

§ 1-2-600. CREATION, DUTIES.
   (A)   There shall be a Frederick County Small Business Advisory Commission
hereinafter referred to as "the Commission".
   (B)   The Commission shall act as an advisory body that serves as a means
for small businesses to be heard and understood, facilitate civic engagement,
and legitimize issues of importance to small businesses operating in Frederick
County.
   (C)   Among its responsibilities and duties the Commission shall:
      (1)   Advise the County Council on ways to enhance and improve the
business climate for small businesses in Frederick County;
      (2)   Represent the views and the needs on behalf of the small business
community;
      (3)   Monitor, analyze, and make recommendations for existing or proposed
legislation of the county government for their impact on small businesses;
      (4)   Review existing Frederick County ordinances for recommended changes
through legislation to improve the business climate in Frederick County;
      (5)   Review regulations and make recommendations on issues under the
authority of county government that could be altered to enhance the business
climate for small businesses in Frederick County; and
      (6)   Within one year of the Commission's first meeting, and annually
thereafter, the Commission shall submit a report to the County Council. The
report shall include recommendations as identified above.
   (D)   Two years following the first meeting, the Commission will submit a
status report to the County Council. The report should include assessment
findings and recommendations as identified above. Upon submission of this
report, the County Council may submit questions or requests to the Commission
for additional information. The Commission will have eight weeks to respond to
any requests. Upon completion of this review, the Council must vote whether to
reauthorize the Commission.
(Bill No. 21-06, 6-15-21)
§ 1-2-601. COMPOSITION.
   (A)   The County Council must appoint the following individuals to serve on
the Commission for a three-year term unless otherwise noted:
      (1)   One member selected by the Frederick County Chamber of Commerce;
      (2)   One member selected by the Downtown Frederick Partnership;
      (3)   One member selected by a non-profit entity that advocates on behalf
of small businesses;
      (4)   One member selected by the Frederick Farm Bureau;
      (5)   One member selected by the Business Law Section of the Frederick
County Bar Association;
      (6)   One member of Visit Frederick; and
      (7)   Two members belonging to municipal business organizations;
   (B)   The following individuals shall serve as ex-officio, non-voting
members with no terms assigned:
      (1)   The County Council member sponsoring this bill. If the Commission
is reauthorized, the Council member who moved to extend the term of the
Commission shall serve as a member; and
      (2)   A member of the Frederick County Office of Economic Development.
   (C)   Members of the Commission shall continue to serve until their
replacement is appointed by the County Council.
(Bill No. 21-06, 6-15-21)
§ 1-2-602. CHAIR, VICE-CHAIR.
   The Coordinating Council must elect a Chair and Vice-Chair from among its
members to serve two-year terms.
(Bill No. 21-06, 6-15-21)
§ 1-2-603. RULES.
   The Coordinating Council shall adopt rules to govern its procedures and
activities.
(Bill No. 21-06, 6-15-21)
§ 1-2-604. COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Coordinating Council shall receive no compensation for their
services.
(Bill No. 21-06, 6-15-21)
§ 1-2-605. MEETINGS AND QUORUM.
   (A)   The Commission shall meet no less than four times annually, but may
not meet more than once a month.
   (B)   A majority of the Commission members shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of regular business.
(Bill No. 21-06, 6-15-21)
ARTICLE XVII: OFFICE OF EQUITY AND INCLUSION AND EQUITY AND
INCLUSION COMMISSION (§§ 1-2-700 — 1-2-709)
Section

1-2-703   Creation and purpose
   
1-2-704   Duties

DIVISION 1. OFFICE OF EQUITY AND INCLUSION
§ 1-2-700. DEFINITIONS.
   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall
have the meanings ascribed to them in this section.
   EQUITY. An intentional and systemic approach to remedy and address
historical practices, policies, and structures that have produced distinct
disparate outcomes which have resulted in the oppression, marginalization,
hindrance to the success of, and restricted access to opportunities and
benefits for historically underrepresented and oppressed populations. The goal
of equity is achievement of equitable outcomes for all.
   INCLUSION. More than simply diversity and numerical representation.
Inclusion exists when historically oppressed and marginalized groups are
empowered to participate in all elements of society in a manner that is
culturally relevant to them, and when their full engagement is both welcomed
and exercised to the degree that it redefines and helps to shape communities
and culture. True inclusion requires changing or eliminating various historical
practices that limit, hinder, and fail to provide opportunities for members of
historically oppressed and marginalized groups to contribute, lead, and
influence decisions and outcomes.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
§ 1-2-701. CREATION AND PURPOSE.
   (A)   There shall be an Office of Equity and Inclusion (hereinafter referred
to as the "Office") in the Office of the County Executive of Frederick County,
Maryland.
   (B)   The Office will raise and sustain the visibility of equity and
inclusion as a leadership, social, and economic imperative for the county.
   (C)   The functions of the Office shall include, but not be limited to the
following:
      (1)   Develop and provide management of a strategic framework to shape,
direct and advance racial, gender, ethnic, inclusion and social equity
priorities and to achieve equitable opportunities within all levels of county
government and for all residents in Frederick County;
      (2)   Work to ensure county employees are aware of Frederick County's
diversity, inclusion and equity goals and to provide employees with the
opportunity to take on an active role in fostering a county-wide culture that
acknowledges, values and celebrates diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging
within all levels of Frederick County Government;
      (3)   Coordinate with county divisions to initiate organizational change
through utilization of an equity lens that results in equity-informed planning,
policy development and decision-making, as well as in the development of
legislation;
      (4)   Provide staff support to the Equity and Inclusion Commission, work
with, evaluate and act on, as appropriate, the recommendations of the Equity
and Inclusion Council;
      (5)   Develop and implement programs, services and trainings for county
staff and county residents that support achievement of the county's diversity,
equity, inclusion and belonging goals;
      (6)   Coordinate with and refer complaints or issues of discrimination to
the Human Relations Department and Commission, as appropriate;
      (7)   Create a review process of bills and resolutions, including the
preparation of an impact statement, that will assist the Council in the
legislative function; and
      (8)   Report annually, on or before July 1, to the County Executive and
County Council, goals, activities, accomplishments and outcomes.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
§ 1-2-702. STAFF.
   (A)   The Office of Equity and Inclusion will include a Chief Equity and
Inclusion Officer (CEIO) to carry out the responsibilities of the Office. The
County Executive shall appoint the CEIO, subject to confirmation of the
Council. The CEIO will serve at the pleasure of the Executive.
   (B)   At the discretion of the County Executive, the Office staff or
structure may be modified or expanded to meet the goals of the Diversity,
Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging Strategic Plan.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
DIVISION 2. EQUITY AND INCLUSION COMMISSION
§ 1-2-703. CREATION AND PURPOSE.
   (A)   There shall be a Frederick County Equity and Inclusion Commission
(hereinafter referred to as "the Commission").
   (B)   The Commission shall act as an advisory body to the Frederick County
Executive, County Council, and the CEIO. The Commission will help identify
issues, concerns, and needs of county residents to improve diversity, equity,
inclusion, and belonging and make recommendations as appropriate.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
§ 1-2-704. DUTIES.
   (A)   Advise and work collaboratively with the Chief Equity and Inclusion
Officer on issues of diversity, equity and inclusion issues such as:
      (1)   Enhancing and improving equitable and fair access to county
government opportunities, resources and services;
      (2)   Conducting community education and awareness to encourage dialogue
and understanding; and
      (3)   Examining and analyzing the impacts of Frederick County Government
policy, practice, and services in relation to equity and inclusion.
   (B)   Provide assistance in the planning of community outreach, initiatives,
and events that affirm, celebrate, and advance diversity, equity and inclusion
throughout the county;
   (C)   Coordinate its engagement and advocacy with the Human Relations
Commission, and other Commissions as appropriate;
   (D)   Refer potential complaints of discrimination to the Human Relations
Department;
   (E)   Provide input on the Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging
Strategic Plan or framework as developed by the Office of Equity and Inclusion
and the Chief Equity and Inclusion Officer; and
   (F)   Prepare a report annually, on or before July 1, to the County
Executive and County Council of the Commission's activities, accomplishments
and outcomes.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
§ 1-2-705. APPOINTMENTS AND MEMBERS.
   (A)   Members. The County Executive shall appoint, subject to confirmation
by the County Council, members of the Commission. The Commission shall consist
of 13 members, who shall be registered voters and residents of the county, and
should reflect a range of ethnicities, professional backgrounds, socioeconomic
status, and places of origin to reflect the racial, economic, and linguistic
diversity of the county. All members should have a commitment to building
equity, inclusion, and understanding of the issues regarding diversity, equity
and inclusion, as evidenced by knowledge and awareness of cultural competency,
structural and institutional barriers to equity, previous work or leadership,
particularly in traditionally marginalized communities. The County Executive
shall strive to include individuals from the following groups:
      (1)   One at-large member who has shown a commitment to diversity and
inclusion within the county;
      (2)   One member from local African American serving organization;
      (3)   One member from a local Hispanic or Latina serving organization;
      (4)   One member from a local Asian American serving organization;
      (5)   One member from an organization working in affordable housing;
      (6)   One member from a locally owned minority business;
      (7)   One member from a local higher education institution;
      (8)   One member from Frederick County Public Schools;
      (9)   One member from local clergy;
      (10)   One member representing the LGBTQ community;
      (11)   One member from the Frederick County Health Department;
      (12)   One member from law enforcement; and
      (13)   One member from the Frederick County Human Relations Commission.
   (B)   Term. Members will serve for a three-year term as a volunteer without
compensation. A member may not serve more than two consecutive full terms. The
initial terms of members shall be staggered so that one-third of members shall
serve an initial term of three years, one-third of members shall serve an
initial term of two years, and one-third of members shall serve an initial term
of one year.
      (1)   An initial term of one or two years shall not be considered a full
term.
      (2)   Any member who is appointed to fill a vacancy shall not be
considered to have served a full term.
      (3)   Vacancies for an unexpired term shall be filled on the same basis
as the original appointment. Members appointed in this way shall continue in
office until their successors are appointed and qualified.
   (C)   Removal. The County Executive may remove a member for neglect or
inability to perform the duties of the office.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
§ 1-2-706. CHAIR, VICE-CHAIR.
   The Commission shall annually elect one member as Chair and another as Vice-
Chair.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
§ 1-2-707. MEETINGS AND QUORUM.
   (A)   The Commission shall meet as frequently as determined by the Chair as
often as required to perform its duties, but not less than six meetings
annually.
   (B)   All meetings shall be subject to the Open Meetings Act.
   (C)   A majority of the Commission members shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
§ 1-2-708. RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Commission shall be subject to Robert's New Rules of Order, but may
adopt additional rules to govern its procedures and activities.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
§ 1-2-709. COUNTY STAFF.
   Staff assistance shall be provided by the Office of the County Executive and
the Chief Equity and Inclusion Officer.
(Bill No. 21-10, 10-19-21)
ARTICLE XVIII: POLICE ACCOUNTABILITY BOARD AND ADMINISTRATIVE CHARGING
COMMITTEE
Section
   
1-2-800   Definitions
   
1-2-801   Creation, duties
   
1-2-802   Composition
   
1-2-803   Chairperson
   
1-2-804   Meetings, quorum, records
   
1-2-805   Complaints
   
1-2-806   Administrative Charging Committee
   
1-2-807   Ethics
   
1-2-808   Effective date
§ 1-2-800. DEFINITIONS.
   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall
have the meanings ascribed to them in this section.
   IMMEDIATE FAMILY MEMBER. A spouse and dependent children.
   LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY. A governmental police force, sheriff's office, or
law enforcement organization of the state, a county, or a municipal corporation
that by statute, ordinance, or common law is authorized to enforce the general
criminal laws of the state.
   POLICE MISCONDUCT. A pattern, practice, or conduct by a police officer or
law enforcement agency that includes:
      (1)   Depriving persons of rights protected by the Constitution or laws
of the state or the United States;
      (2)   A violation of a criminal statute; or
      (3)   A violation of law enforcement agency standards and policies.
   POLICE OFFICER. "Police Officer" has the meaning set forth in § 3-201 of the
Public Safety Article of the State Code.
(Bill No. 22-09, 4-26-2022)
§ 1-2-801. CREATION, DUTIES.
   (A)   There is a Frederick County Police Accountability Board, which
consists of 11 voting members, appointed by the County Executive and confirmed
by the County Council, as set forth below.
   (B)   Budget and staff. The County Executive shall propose a budget for the
Board that shall be included in the annual budget and appropriation ordinance
adopted by the County Council and shall assign staff as needed to the Board,
including the designation of an Executive Administrator.
   (C)   The Board shall:
      (1)   Hold quarterly meetings, and additional meetings if necessary, with
heads of law enforcement agencies and otherwise work with law enforcement
agencies with jurisdiction in the county and county government to improve
matters of policing;
      (2)   Appoint civilian members to Charging Committees and trial boards;
      (3)   Receive complaints of police misconduct filed by members of the
public;
      (4)   On a quarterly basis, review outcomes of disciplinary matters
considered by Charging Committees; and
      (5)   On or before December 31 each year, submit a report to the County
Executive and the County Council of the county, and each municipality located
within Frederick County that maintains a police agency that:
         (a)   Identifies any trends in the disciplinary process of police
officers in the county; and
         (b)   Makes recommendations on changes to policy, training, or
supervision that would improve police accountability in the county.
(Bill No. 22-09, 4-26-2022)
§ 1-2-802. COMPOSITION.
   (A)   Subject to the confirmation of the County Council, the County
Executive must appoint 11 individuals to serve on the Board as regular, voting
members for a three-year term unless otherwise noted.
   (B)   To the maximum extent practicable, the membership of the Board shall
reflect the racial, gender, and cultural diversity of the county as well as
representation from communities that experience a higher frequency of
interactions with law enforcement, including but not limited to people who are
Black/African-American, Latino, and lesbian/gay/bisexual/transgender/queer
(LGBTQ), first or second generation immigrants, people with disabilities,
people with behavioral health concerns, and people who have experienced
homelessness.
   (C)   Regular, voting members of the Board must:
      (1)   Be at least 21 years of age, residents of Frederick County, legal
residents or citizens of the United States, and registered voters. To the
extent practicable, the membership of the Police Accountability Board shall
reflect the racial, gender, cultural diversity, and geography of the county;
      (2)   Be county residents, to include:
         (a)   Two residents of the City of Frederick;
         (b)   One resident of the City of Brunswick;
         (c)   One resident of the Town of Thurmont;
         (d)   One resident who is Black or African-American; and
         (e)   One resident who is a first or second generation immigrant.
      (3)   Have familiarity or experience within the legal field, the
behavioral health field, social services, human resources or personnel
management, the operation of a government agency, criminal justice agency,
community service organization, or relevant lived experience;
      (4)   Participate in an in-person or virtual interview and appropriate
background research conducted by:
         (a)   The County Executive or designee;
         (b)   The municipal mayors of the Cities of Frederick and Brunswick
and the Town of Thurmont, or their Chief Administrative Officer or equivalent;
and
         (c)   Other individuals as determined by the County Executive.
      (5)   Successfully complete training on matters related to police
procedures from the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission, the
County Ethics Law, the Open Meetings Act, and any other training required by
the State, the County Executive, or majority vote of the Board. A ride along
with a police officer to observe the workday is encouraged.
      (6)   Sign an agreement to maintain the confidentiality of all Board
matters related to individual complaints until final disposition and all
appeals have been exhausted.
   (D)   An individual may not be a member of the Board if:
      (1)   They are, or an immediate family member is, an active police
officer as defined in § 3-201 of the Public Safety Article of the Annotated
Code of Maryland; or
      (2)   They have been convicted of, or received a probation before
judgement for, a felony or a misdemeanor with a statutory penalty of more than
two years.
   (E)   The following individuals shall serve as liaisons to the Board for
purposes of serving as a resource and answering questions as needed or
requested by the Board:
      (1)   A designee of the Chief of Police of each municipal police agency
within the county;
      (2)   A designee of the Sheriff; and
      (3)   The Frederick County Chief Equity and Inclusion Officer.
   (F)   Of the initial appointees to the Board, three appointees shall have a
term of one year, four appointees shall have a term of two years, and four
appointees, one of which shall be the chairperson, shall have a term of three
years. Members may be reappointed, but may not serve more than two full
consecutive three-year terms.
   (G)   A member may be removed from the Board if at any time they fail to
meet the requirements of this section or any other requirement for members of
the Board or, fail to attend at least 75% of the meetings during any period of
12 consecutive months.
   (H)   Vacancies shall be filled on the same basis as the original
appointments for the unexpired terms. Members shall continue in office until
their successors are appointed and qualified.
(Bill No. 22-09, 4-26-2022; Bill No. 25-08, 6-17-2025)
§ 1-2-803. CHAIRPERSON.
   The County Executive shall nominate, and the County Council shall approve,
an individual to serve as the Board Chairperson who shall have familiarity with
criminal justice or other relevant experience needed for the position. The term
of the chairperson is two years.
(Bill No. 22-09, 4-26-2022; Bill No. 25-08, 6-17-2025)
§ 1-2-804. MEETINGS, QUORUM, RECORDS.
   (A)   The Board shall meet at least quarterly.
   (B)   A majority of the Board members shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of regular business.
   (C)   The meetings of the Board shall be subject to the Open Meetings Act.
   (D)   The Board members shall be subject to the Frederick County Ethics Law.
   (E)   The Board shall be authorized to create subcommittees.
   (F)   Records shall be maintained by the Executive Administrator pursuant to
a record retention schedule created by County Administration in accordance with
state law. The Board and its staff shall keep confidential any records
prohibited from disclosure under the Maryland Public Information Act.
(Bill No. 22-09, 4-26-2022; Bill No. 25-08, 6-17-2025)
§ 1-2-805. COMPLAINTS.
   (A)   The Board shall receive complaints of police misconduct filed by
members of the public or forwarded to them from a police agency.
   (B)   The Board, in conjunction with the law enforcement agencies located
within the county, shall establish a uniform procedure for allowing members of
the public to file complaints of police misconduct.
   (C)   A complaint of police misconduct filed with the Board or law
enforcement agency shall include:
      (1)   The name of the police officer accused of misconduct;
      (2)   A description of the facts on which the complaint is based;
      (3)   Contact information of the complainant or a person filing on behalf
of the complainant for investigative follow-up; and
      (4)   A complaint need not be notarized.
   (D)   A complaint of police misconduct filed with the Board shall be
forwarded to the appropriate law enforcement agency within three business days
after receipt by the Board.
(Bill No. 22-09, 4-26-2022)
§ 1-2-806. ADMINISTRATIVE CHARGING COMMITTEE.
   (A)   There shall be an Administrative Charging Committee to serve
countywide law enforcement agencies and local law enforcement agencies within
Frederick County.
   (B)   The Committee shall:
      (1)   Meet once per month or as needed;
      (2)   Review the findings of a law enforcement agency's investigation
conducted and forwarded in accordance with state law;
      (3)   Make a determination that the police officer who is subject to
investigation shall be:
         (a)   Administratively charged; or
         (b)   Not administratively charged.
      (4)   If the police officer is charged, recommend discipline in
accordance with the law enforcement agency's disciplinary matrix established in
accordance with state law;
      (5)   Review any body camera footage that may be relevant to the matters
covered in the complaint of misconduct;
      (6)   Authorize a police officer called to appear before the Committee to
be accompanied by a representative;
      (7)   Issue a written opinion that describes in detail its findings,
determinations, and recommendations; and
      (8)   Forward a written opinion to the chief of the law enforcement
agency, the police office, and the complainant.
   (C)   In executing its duties, the Committee may:
      (1)   Request information or action from the law enforcement agency that
conducted the investigation, including requiring additional investigation and
the issuance of subpoenas;
      (2)   If the police officer is not administratively charged, make a
determination that:
         (a)   The allegations against the police officer are unfounded; or
         (b)   The police officer is exonerated.
      (3)   Record, in writing, any failure of policy, training, or supervision
that caused or contributed to a police officer's misconduct.
   (D)   Membership; term.
      (1)   Sign an agreement to maintain the confidentiality of all Committee
matters related to individual complaints until final disposition and all
appeals have been exhausted.
      (2)   Before serving as a member of the Committee, an individual shall
successfully complete training on matters relating to police procedures from
the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission, the County Ethics Law,
the Open Meetings Act, and any other training required by the state, the County
Executive, or a majority vote of the Committee.
      (3)   The Committee shall be comprised of five members.
         (a)   Members shall be at least 21 years of age, legal residents or
citizens of the United States, residents of the county, and registered voters;
         (b)   Be of good moral character and free from bias that would
negatively impact the integrity of the Committee; and
         (c)   Have familiarity or experience within the legal field, the
behavioral health field, social services, human resources or personnel
management, the operation of a government agency, criminal justice agency, or
community service organization.
      (4)   An individual may not be a member of the Committee if:
         (a)   They are, or an immediate family member is, an active police
officer as defined in § 3-201 of the Public Safety Article of the Annotated
Code of Maryland;
         (b)   They are an employee of a police agency located within Frederick
County;
         (c)   They are under criminal investigation by any police agency;
         (d)   They are currently charged with a crime that is pending before
any court; or
         (e)   They have been convicted of, or received a probation before
judgement for, a felony or a misdemeanor with a statutory penalty of one year
or more.
      (5)   The Chairperson of the Police Accountability Board, or a member of
the Board designated by the chairperson, shall serve as a member of the
Committee.
      (6)   The County Executive shall appoint two civilians as members of the
Committee.
      (7)   The Police Accountability Board shall appoint two civilians as
members of the Committee.
      (8)   Subject to division (D)(9) below, members shall serve a term of two
years and shall not be eligible for reappointment after a total of five
consecutive years of service on the Committee.
      (9)   The initial terms of one civilian appointed by the County Executive
and one civilian appointed by the Police Accountability Board shall be one
year.
      (10)   The Committee shall elect a chairperson annually from among its
members by majority vote each first meeting occurring on or after October 1.
      (11)   The Chairperson of the Committee shall serve no more than two
consecutive terms as chairperson.
      (12)   Of the initial appointees to the Committee, two appointees shall
have a term of one year, and three appointees, one of which shall be the
chairperson, shall have a term of two years. Members may be reappointed, but
may not serve more than two full consecutive two-year terms.
      (13)   A Committee member may be removed by a majority vote of the
Committee if at any time they fail to meet the requirements of this section or
any other requirement for members of the Committee or fail to attend at least
75% of the meetings during any period of 12 consecutive months.
      (14)   A majority of the members of the Committee shall constitute a
quorum for the transaction of regular business.
      (15)   Vacancies shall be filled on the same basis as the original
appointments for the unexpired terms. Members shall continue in office until
their successors are appointed and qualified.
(Bill No. 22-09, 4-26-2022; Bill No. 25-08, 6-17-2025)
§ 1-2-807. ETHICS.
   (A)   Members of the Police Accountability Board and the Administrative
Charging Committee shall be subject to the Frederick County Ethics Law.
   (B)   No member of the Police Accountability Board or the Administrative
Charging Committee shall cast a vote on any matter where a conflict of interest
exists. For the purposes of this section, a conflict of interest occurs when a
member's personal interests could compromise his or her judgment, decisions, or
actions. Personal interests could include, but are not limited to, the
following: employer/employee relationships, familial relationships,
friendships, financial, or social factors.
(Bill No. 22-09, 4-26-2022)
§ 1-2-808. EFFECTIVE DATE.
   In accordance with House Bill No. 670 enacted as Chapter 59 of the Laws of
Maryland by the Maryland General Assembly during its 2021 Session, the Board
may not engage in any of the activities listed in § 3-102 of the Public Safety
Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland until July 1, 2022.
(Bill No. 22-09, 4-26-2022)
ARTICLE XIX: BOARD OF HEALTH
Section
   
1-2-900   Creation, purpose, powers
   
1-2-901   Membership
   
1-2-902   Liaisons
   
1-2-903   Meetings, attendance
   
1-2-904   Staffing
   
1-2-905   Regulations
§ 1-2-900. CREATION, PURPOSE, POWERS.
   (A)   There shall be a Frederick County Board of Health.
   (B)   The Frederick County Board of Health shall:
      (1)   Have the powers and duties granted to a local board of health under
state law, including those provided in Md. Code Ann. Title 3 of the Health-
General Article.
      (2)   Assist and cooperate with the Secretary of the Maryland Department
of Health of the State of Maryland in health-related matters, including
behavioral health.
      (3)   Have general responsibility for the health and sanitary interests
of the people of the county including the investigation and study of the causes
of disease, epidemics and nuisances affecting public health, behavioral health,
the prevention of contagious diseases, and the preservation of health.
      (4)   Advise the County Executive and County Council on health matters
including behavioral health.
      (5)   Have the power to administer oaths, issue subpoenas and apply for
injunctive relief.
      (6)   At the request of the CE or a majority of the County Council, the
Frederick County Health Officer (or their alternate) will convene a meeting of
the Board of Health to review and make recommendations on any matter related to
public health.
(Bill No. 23-06, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-901. MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   The membership of the Board of Health shall consist of the seven
Frederick County Council members, the County Executive, and the Frederick
County Health Officer.
   (B)   The Frederick County Health Officer shall serve as the executive
officer and secretary, and need not be a resident of Frederick County or a
registered voter.
   (C)   All members shall have full voting privileges.
   (D)   All members will serve without additional compensation.
(Bill No. 23-06, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-902. LIAISONS.
   (A)   In addition to the members above, the Board shall appoint the
following liaisons:
      (1)   An epidemiologist;
      (2)   A nurse;
      (3)   A mental health professional;
      (4)   A veterinarian;
      (5)   A member from the Frederick Chamber of Commerce; and
      (6)   One person with a science related background.
   (B)   Liaisons shall be appointed and confirmed by a majority of the Board
of Health.
   (C)   Liaisons shall have no voting privileges, and will not be counted in
determining presence of a quorum.
   (D)   Liaisons will serve without compensation. Subject to subsection (E),
the term of office of each of the members shall be for a period of three years.
   (E)   Of the initial six appointed liaisons, two shall be appointed for a
term that expires in one year, two shall be appointed for a term that expires
in two years, and two shall be appointed for a term that expires in three
years.
   (F)   Liaisons may be reappointed but may not serve more than two full
consecutive three-year terms.
   (G)   Vacancies shall be filled on the same basis as the original
appointments for unexpired terms and shall be filled with a person of the same
or similar background of the liaison being replaced. Liaisons shall continue in
office until their successors are appointed and qualified.
   (H)   Liaisons shall serve as a resource, provide information and data, and
answer questions as needed or requested by the Board of Health.
(Bill No. 23-06, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-903. MEETINGS, ATTENDANCE.
   (A)   The Frederick County Board of Health shall meet in May and October of
each year and at any other time the Board considers necessary.
   (B)   Meetings shall take place at a Frederick County location which is open
and accessible to the public.
   (C)   A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of business.
   (D)   Any motion of the Board requires the affirmative vote of at least five
members to pass.
(Bill No. 23-06, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-904. STAFFING.
   Staffing to the Board of Health shall be provided by the Frederick County
Health Department.
(Bill No. 23-06, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-905. REGULATIONS.
   Any regulation approved by the BOH shall contain a specific date and time
when the regulation shall go into effect.
(Bill No. 23-06, 4-18-2023)
ARTICLE XX: FREDERICK COUNTY BEHAVIORAL HEALTH ADVISORY COUNCIL
Section
   
1-2-1000   Creation, duties
   
1-2-1001   Membership
   
1-2-1002   Terms
   
1-2-1003   Chair, Vice-Chair
   
1-2-1004   Meetings, quorum
   
1-2-1005   Rules
§ 1-2-1000. CREATION, DUTIES.
   (A)   In accordance with Md. Code Ann. Title 10, Subtitle 3, Part II of the
Health-General Article for the provision of Joint Mental Health and Addictions
Advisory Committees, there shall be a Frederick County Behavioral Health
Advisory Council ("Council").
   (B)   Powers. The Council may:
      (1)   Create subcommittees;
      (2)   Have additional members participate as needed; and
      (3)   Consult with state and county agencies to obtain such technical
assistance and advice as it considers necessary to complete its duties.
   (C)   Duties. The Council shall:
      (1)   Monitor, review and evaluate the allocation and adequacy of
publicly funded behavioral health services within the county;
      (2)   Determine the needs of the county behavioral health system,
including quality of services, gaps in the system, and interagency
coordination;
      (3)   Participate in the development of the local behavioral health plan
and budget;
      (4)   Prepare and disseminate an annual report in form and to required
parties in accordance with Md. Code Ann. § 10-312 of the Health-General
Article;
      (5)   Review and comment on the annual county behavioral health plan and
preliminary budget, before submission of the budget to the state; and
      (6)   Review and comment on the Frederick County Health Department's
annual fiscal report to the Maryland Department of Health.
(Bill. No. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-1001. MEMBERSHIP.
   The Council shall include the following:
   (A)   As nonvoting ex officio members, the following individuals or their
designees:
      (1)   The Health Officer for the county;
      (2)   A representative of a state inpatient facility that serves the
county, appointed as provided in subsection (A)(2) of this section;
      (3)   The Director of Behavioral Health Services Division, Frederick
County Health Department;
      (4)   The Director of the Local Behavioral Health Authority; and
      (5)   A representative from the County Council.
   (B)   As voting members and representatives of the county's major socio-
economic and ethnic groups:
      (1)   The County Executive shall appoint at least five, but not more than
seven, representatives selected from among the following:
         (a)   The Office of the County Executive;
         (b)   The Superintendent of Frederick County Public Schools, or the
Superintendent's designee;
         (c)   The Director of the County's Department of Social Services, or
the Director's designee;
         (d)   Practicing physicians;
         (e)   Behavioral health professionals who are not physicians;
         (f)   Clergy;
         (g)   Practicing legal professional;
         (h)   The head of a local law enforcement agency, or their designee;
         (i)   A county general hospital that contains an inpatient behavioral
health unit;
         (j)   The Director of the County Division of Senior Services, or the
Director's designee;
         (k)   The Regional Director of the Department of Juvenile Services, or
the Director's designee;
         (l)   The Director of the Division of Fire and Rescue Services, or the
Director's designee;
         (m)   A community rehabilitation or housing program that operates in
the county; and
      (2)   The County Executive shall appoint at least two but not more than
four members, selected from among the following groups or organizations:
         (a)   Individuals who are currently receiving or who have in the past
received behavioral health services;
         (b)   Parents or other relatives of adults with behavioral health
disorders;
         (c)   Parents or other relatives of children or adolescents with
emotional, behavioral, or mental health disorders the onset of which occurred
during childhood or adolescence;
         (d)   The Frederick County Mental Health Association; and
         (e)   A member of the general public.
   (C)   The County Executive may appoint any additional non-voting members to
the Council as necessary to advise and advocate about behavioral health issues.
(Bill. No. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-1002. TERMS.
   (A)   The term of an appointed member is three years and begins on July 1.
   (B)   Staggered terms. Of the initial members one-third shall be appointed
for a three- year term, one-third shall be appointed to a two-year term and
one-third shall be appointed for a one-year term which shall end each year on
June 30.
   (C)   Term limits. A member who serves two consecutive full three-year terms
may not be reappointed for two years after completion of those terms.
   (D)   Compensation. Members of the Council shall receive no compensation.
(Bill. No. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-1003. CHAIR, VICE-CHAIR.
   (A)   The Council shall elect annually a Chair and Vice-Chair from among its
members to serve a single year term.
   (B)   A member may not serve as Chair for more than two consecutive years.
   (C)   The Chair shall preside at all meetings of the Council.
   (D)   The Vice Chair shall assume all duties of the Chair in the absence of
the Chair and shall perform other duties as assigned by the Chair.
   (E)   The Council may elect other officers as needed. The manner of election
of additional officers shall be as the Council determines.
(Bill. No. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-1004. MEETINGS, QUORUM.
   (A)   Meetings. The Council shall have not fewer than six meetings per year
at the times and places that the Council determines.
   (B)   Quorum.
      (1)   A majority of the voting members present of the Council shall
constitute a quorum for the transaction of business; and
      (2)   An affirmative vote by the majority of those present at any meeting
shall be sufficient for any official action.
   (C)   Staff. The Health Officer or the Health Officer's designee shall
provide staff services for the Council.
(Bill. No. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
§ 1-2-1005. RULES.
   The Council shall adopt rules to govern its procedures and activities.
(Bill. No. 23-07, 4-18-2023)
ARTICLE XXI: BICYCLE AND PEDESTRIAN ADVISORY COMMISSION
Section
   
1-2-1006   Creation, duties
   
1-2-1007   Composition
   
1-2-1008   Chair, Vice-Chair
   
1-2-1009   Rules
   
1-2-1010   Compensation

§ 1-2-1006. CREATION, DUTIES.
   (A)   There shall be a Frederick County Bicycle and Pedestrian Advisory
Commission hereinafter referred to as "the Commission".
   (B)   The Commission shall act as an advisory body that advises County
officials and staff on the sound development, management, and safe use of the
County's pedestrian and bicycle systems as they relate to infrastructure,
accessibility, and promoting the benefits of these systems.
   (C)   Among its responsibilities and duties, the Commission shall:
      (1)   Review the annual Capital Improvement Program and provide to the
County Executive and County Council recommendations regarding funding for
projects relating to bicycling and pedestrian transportation;
      (2)   Assist the County with the implementation of the Bikeways and
Trails Plan;
      (3)   Periodically, or at the request of the County Executive or County
Council, provide advice on the development of regulations or policies that
benefit cyclists and pedestrians;
      (4)   Engage in community outreach and education on cycling and
pedestrian initiatives and events; and
      (5)   On or before July 1 of each year, the Commission shall submit an
annual report to the County Executive and County Council. The report shall
include recommendations on the above.
(Bill. No. 23-10, 6-6-2023)
§ 1-2-1007. COMPOSITION.
   (A)   Subject to the confirmation of the County Council, the County
Executive must appoint nine individuals to serve on the Commission for a three-
year term unless otherwise noted.
   (B)   Of the initial nine members, three shall be appointed for a term that
expires in one year, three shall be appointed for a term that expires in two
years, and three shall be appointed for a term that expires in three years.
   (C)   Members may be reappointed but may not serve more than two full
consecutive three-year terms.
   (D)   Members of the Commission shall continue to serve until their
replacement is confirmed by the County Council.
   (E)    A member of the County Council shall serve as an ex-officio, non-
voting member with no term assigned.
   (F)   A County staff member shall be designed by the County Executive to
assist and support the Commission.
(Bill. No. 23-10, 6-6-2023)
§ 1-2-1008. CHAIR, VICE-CHAIR.
   At its first meeting, and biennially thereafter, the Commission must elect a
chair and vice-chair from among its members to serve two-year terms.
(Bill. No. 23-10, 6-6-2023)
§ 1-2-1009. RULES.
   The Commission shall adopt rules to govern its procedures and activities.
(Bill. No. 23-10, 6-6-2023)
§ 1-2-1010. COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Commission shall receive no compensation for their services.
(Bill. No. 23-10, 6-6-2023)
§ 1-2-1011. MEETINGS AND QUORUM.
   (A)   The Commission shall meet with the frequency it determines necessary
to perform its functions but there shall be no less than four meetings
annually.
   (B)   A majority of the then-serving Commission members shall constitute a
quorum for the transaction of regular business.
(Bill. No. 23-10, 6-6-2023)
ARTICLE XXII: SCOTT KEY CENTER ADVISORY BOARD
